newsitem.title: UK: Clarke says decision to delay EMU could come soon.
newsitem.headline: Clarke says decision to delay EMU could come soon.

text.p: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke, repeating his view that a single currency is unlikely to start in January 1999, said a decision to delay it could be announced within a few months.
"I continue to believe it's not likely that enough countries will be sufficiently convergent at the first of January 1999," he said on BBC Television's Business Breakfast programme.
"So personally, I think there will be a postponement of it. Perhaps in a few months, perhaps a little after that."

Clarke, who was speaking from Davos, Switzerland, said there was a strong political will across the continent to go ahead with monetary union and it would be a considerable blow to the political standing of some governments if it did not happen.
"So there is a commitment to it, but in my view that should be combined with common sense," he said.

"Nobody should contemplate EMU unless countries are genuinely convergent and are going to stay convergent in the economic conditions that are essential to get the best out of a single currency and a single market."
"A country could hit all the measures on the button on one particular year, but if you look behind that you might see that there's little chance of that being sustained," Clarke added.
"What matters is that a low inflation rate culture can be sustained by strong monetary policy."
